When done properly, yes. It's just that the way most people approach relationships in general is a joke, and slapping the label of marriage on it won't make it better. Take OP, for example. Living together with some guy without a trace of commitment for any period of time, let alone several years, is ALREADY a bad outcome. Most people fuck first and ask questions later. They treat each other and their relationships as interchangeable, and this is reflected in their lives after marriage as well. Marriage, to those types, is just a cosmetic change. They'd already had sex, lived together, and coordinated their finances before marriage, so what changes afterwards? And if they did all those things not only with their spouse-to-be but previous exes, is there any real sense of uniqueness to the marriage?

tl;dr don't live together or have sex outside of marriage, insist on the same from a partner, and the "50%" divorce rate is slashed down to 10% or lower as long as you take your time and find someone you actually want to be with.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I have an "inner critic" that lingers and flares up on occasion. Downplays my achievements, overexaggerates my mistakes, and wants me to manipulate in order to protect myself from the imagined consequences. I've never practiced self-harm but it really likes to tell me to kill myself.

Letting it take control of you will lead to disastrous consequences. I'm in the process of changing careers because of it. But ignoring it isn't the answer either, at least not until much later.

You need to mentally identify it apart from your core self and give it a voice without giving it control. Listen to it and reason with it.

You are not going to be able to block its intrusive thoughts out anytime soon, you and it both know it, but practicing progressive restrictions can stack up overtime to creep power away from it. Start on order of importance, work your way up, and expect relapse. If your "internalized abuser" makes you say its thoughts out loud, use your vocals to instead recognize flaws in its ways, express direct present emotions (always start with "I feel"), anything to establish boundaries between you and it. It will hate it, and it will fight it. But it will eventually learn. And once it does, it becomes significantly simpler to process and flush out.

If you can keep your head when all about you
Are losing theirs and blaming it on you,
If you can trust yourself when all men doubt you,
But make allowance for their doubting too;
If you can wait and not be tired by waiting,
Or being lied about, don’t deal in lies,
Or being hated, don’t give way to hating,
And yet don’t look too good, nor talk too wise:

If you can dream—and not make dreams your master;
If you can think—and not make thoughts your aim;
If you can meet with Triumph and Disaster
And treat those two impostors just the same;
If you can bear to hear the truth you’ve spoken
Twisted by knaves to make a trap for fools,
Or watch the things you gave your life to, broken,
And stoop and build ’em up with worn-out tools:

If you can make one heap of all your winnings
And risk it on one turn of pitch-and-toss,
And lose, and start again at your beginnings
And never breathe a word about your loss;
If you can force your heart and nerve and sinew
To serve your turn long after they are gone,
And so hold on when there is nothing in you
Except the Will which says to them: ‘Hold on!’

If you can talk with crowds and keep your virtue,
Or walk with Kings—nor lose the common touch,
If neither foes nor loving friends can hurt you,
If all men count with you, but none too much;
If you can fill the unforgiving minute
With sixty seconds’ worth of distance run,
Yours is the Earth and everything that’s in it,
And—which is more—you’ll be a Man, my son!

Yes. When you’re trying to quit, and you keep thinking “I want the drug”, and you eventually exhaust your willpower, the underlying mechanism is there’s an uncomfortable feeling in your body and mind, and the mind automatically equates this with wanting the drug, because that’s how it has been trained to interpret it. And you can only forcibly keep it at an arms length for so long. But you can decide not to try to get rid of that feeling. Strip it of its learned meaning. And relax with it. And you’ll find all it really is, is raw energy. It may be painful, uncomfortable, etc… But as you embrace it and relax into those sensations, and you stay that way as you go through your daily life, it becomes transformative instead. You’ll find that inside of that feeling you’re trying to not have to feel by using the drug, there’s all the energy and motivation you could ask for to change your life. It will feel soulful and like you are finally becoming whole. People only lack energy and motivation because they have opted for numbness

Hi OP, Tet is just lunar new year/chinese new year for Vietnamese people. Fun holiday if you spend it with people u care about. Celebrating it with ur bf sounds like a great idea and if i were ur bf i would love u even more.

U can try and make pho, but a lot of people dislike the amount of work put in and time. U could always just buy from viet businesses or in a local viet town (like china town)

Look up Banh Tet. Eating Pho is great and you can eat it for breakfast, but in the spirit of the holiday, buying or making Banh Tet is pretty cool. The word Banh is like, generic for something solid+glutenous i guess, like rice or bread or sugary sometimes. Not always like dessert.
Banh Tet is Pork and mung beans wrapped in sticky rice wrapped in banana leaves, and maybe try to get ones with maybe less sticky rice (larger ratio of tasty meat+mung bean). Unless ur a seasoned cook, please dont try to make it urself - not that it's hard, but because if it's new to you, it will be time consuming and ull hate urself for screwing up cuz ur buying new ingredients.

At the shops u might also see some classic "viet desserts". Ok realize that chocolate is a new world dish and the east were not blessed with such godly delights. Dried foods and fruits are common. Some are bad (imo) and some are good (imo). Maybe ask around or guess. Have fun with that lol. Coconut based ones are usually good, as are Banh Tam Khoai. Maybe get some milk-based "che"s dessert-drinks(?).

I believe u can just go to ur local chase and ask for 2$ bills in chinese new year red envelopes, when it's in season. Maybe there are spares if out of season. Or just buy from ur local asia-town businesses maybe.
U can also buy lanterns and other fun decor.

Dont think too much about authenticity - focus more on having a fun time

Losing weight and maintaining a healthy weight can be a challenging and time-consuming process that requires a combination of diet and exercise. While there is no easy or "brain dead" way to lose weight, there are a few simple strategies that you can adopt to help you on your weight loss journey:

Eat more fruits and vegetables: Incorporating more fruits and vegetables into your diet can help you feel full and satisfied while also providing important nutrients. Aim for at least five servings of fruits and vegetables each day.

Drink plenty of water: Staying hydrated can help you feel full and may also help with weight loss. Aim to drink at least 8 cups (64 ounces) of water per day.

Get plenty of sleep: Adequate sleep is important for both physical and mental health. Aim for 7-9 hours of sleep per night.

Find an activity you enjoy: Regular physical activity can help with weight loss and maintenance, but it's important to find an activity that you enjoy. This could be walking, dancing, swimming, or any other activity that you find enjoyable.

Be consistent: Making small, consistent changes to your diet and exercise habits can help you see progress over time. Stick with it, even if you don't see results immediately.

It's important to remember that losing weight and maintaining a healthy weight requires a long-term commitment. There is no quick fix or easy solution. With patience and dedication, however, you can make progress towards your weight loss goals.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Eat one meal a day. Eat a pretty plain diet consisting of whole foods. Chew your food thoroughly and eat slowly. Drink more water. Don't buy crap. Don't drink alcohol, juice or sugar sweetened anything. If you find eating related to boredom and you can't stop thinking about food get a hobby and go do that. Ideally take up some low impact exercise like walking, swimming, cycling, home callisthenics etc and incorporate it into your daily routine.

Basically there are better ways to do this involving calorie counting and meal planning with macronutrient splits and stuff, but you asked for easiest. Honestly, if you are fat and moderately active and stick to one basic meal a day you can eat a relatively obscene amount and still lose weight. You can't eat crap though, no sweets, cakes, fried dough, alcohol, soft drinks etc. But a whole skin off chicken, two heads of broccoli and hot sauce? A whole stir fried head of cabbage and a lb of lean pork with some ginger, garlic, black vinegar and onions sauce? If you want rice, pasta, potatoes, bread etc you should control the portions though as you probably have a tendency to overeat those types of food. Eat slowly so you appreciate it and also so you can get used to your body telling you that you are full. There are all sorts of wild hormones going wrong when you are obese and as you get lean you'll find a lot of these things start working right and you have to learn to interpret the signals.

I lost over 150lb doing this. I did a modified protein sparing fast for about 18 months. I did fasted cardio every morning, a basic barbel routine in the evening and lived on green tea, lean meat and vegetables. I swapped alcohol for the bong a couple of evenings a week.

how do i stop fucking drinking?
had my fourth night in a row of drinking all of picrel. a week like this is not uncommon for me, and it's getting to be that i need something stronger as well.

posts.name: Over 3 years sober due to text below
posts.com:
Naltrexone for alcoholism treatment

An addict wanting and trying to quit is a case of the rational mind deciding to stop, while the autonomous processes of the mind create cravings. Its why people have such a hard time losing weight. Rational mind chooses to lose weight and eat less, autonomous mind sends craving signals. One can understand a behavior is worth quitting and try his best to quit, yet repeatedly fail against incessant, powerful urges. Worth noting is that gambling, sex, compulsive overeating, alcoholism and drug addiction are a cluster of similar disorders. A malfunction of the brain's "reward center". See for yourself: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18241634/

Naltrexone is a helpful medication to remove the cravings. Classed as an opiate-antagonist (binds to endorphin receptors w/out "high"), Naltrexone comes in a once-monthly injection or daily pills. Absent insurance, injection is expensive and pills are inexpensive. Public health clinics, aka "community clinics" receive federal and state cost-reduction grants to serve people who lack insurance. Sliding-fee scale for most services and in the case of Naltrexone injection, often free. In the U.S. you can call 211 in most cities, a direct line to United Way. They will help you locate such a clinic. Also some anti-depressants and other psychotropic medications can help. Addicts tend to have mood or other psychiatric issues that are called "co-morbid factors". A doctor at a "community clinic" can help with that also. Naltrexone is typically taken daily for 3+ months.

Drugs.com has 500+ positive reviews about Naltrexone from actual alcoholics.

"Medical detox" refers to a doctor prescribing librium or valium for a few days to get you safely off alcohol. It works and its painless. Trying to "taper down" WITH alcohol is slow and extremely painful. Most doctors will readily offer you a medical detox prescription.

Not schizophrenic but I suspect my mother is. Do you know whether your mother has ever been to therapy? That may be a good starting question to gauge her response. If she says therapy is useless or something like that, you probably aren’t going to get anywhere by suggesting she may have schizophrenia. Mine will not see a therapist and gets violently angry over the suggestion that some of her experiences might not be real, even when I’m trying to frame it in the most supportive light possible. On the other hand, if she supports you in going to therapy and/or says she has gone as well, you may be able to just ask if she’s been diagnosed with anything and tell her it’s for your medical history.
If it turns out she won’t talk about it, just tell your therapist the symptoms she shows and that you don’t know for sure whether they mean anything. That’s what I do.
Also, I wish you luck in mending the relationship, that’s a very upstanding thing to do.

>What actually helped me more than meds, was fitness, sobriety, sleeping a lot, being calm
>Not taking meds but eating healthy and working out and sleeping a lot is better than the opposite in 9/10 schizos
>It gets better with age
>Normies can never understand things we do about reality, abstract concepts, they do drugs but they can't catch up
Best thing you can do, is try and ignore knowledge of having schizophrenia completely, develop your own reality checks and philosophy, in short what is real is not what matters, practical effects do.

Never stress yourself too much, especially not to impress normies or anything. I don't give a shit about hiding, I do weird stuff if I feel like it, I explain what I want to, and I'm always calm and healthy. I lift 5 times a week.I have a lot of energy and lifting helps.

Giving them the benefit of the doubt, I think it comes from a(n unconscious) place of my viewpoints being a threat to their sense of self or worldview. So, essentially, I won't be allowed to reject their gifts. They've already gone through the process of getting them, you see. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27975025
>Can you give me some examples on how I could fuck my uncle over or how he could fuck me over if I don't have a written contract?
Well the house is in his name until you pay it off. Recorded at the county courthouse land deeds. If you paid say $100K of it over the next 10 years and then he died, it is still in his name, so you would lose all that money and be evicted by whomever inherited it. Could be the government if he didn't have a will.
Also, he could get sick, have to go to nursing home, so the government takes the house to pay for it. You lose house.
Another relative could lay claim to it, so you lose house and money.
There might be a lein against the house, and you could have it foreclosed on by the county government and taken from you.
He could take a reverse mortgage against the house, and you lose the house.
Storm damage, fire, rot and decay, etc. Who covers the costs? Who gets the insurance?


There are hundreds of other things that could happen.

Go to a lawyer that specializes in real estate, and have him draw up a sale contract between the two of you, going over it with both of you present, so the lawyer "works for you both" at the same time, and so he doesn't think you are trying to scew him over.

Business is business.

Sup, I'm currently a student there. AMA.

>>27972085
>Is a worth it?
Yes. It's no different than a state college other than it's online, you just pay for a term, and you can get as many courses as you can done within that term without paying more money. A friend of mine who majored in CS currently works as a software engineer for a company based in austin, texas and he makes just over 100k. All that matters in tech is your skill set and whether or not you have a degree; doesn't matter at all where you got the degree. Sure, might be harder to get a job at google or facebook or something with a degree from WGU since they recruit from ivy league universities, but who gives a shit since you'll be just fine working for other companies.
>Do recruiters even recognize online degrees now a days?
I'm 3/4ths of the way through my degree (23 years old btw) and have recruiters hitting me up on handshake and linkedin all the time. I'm doing an unpaid internship for a local software company at the moment but that's only because I'm also working at an amazon warehouse and obviously still doing school work. Like I said, most companies only care that you have a degree, doesn't matter where you got it from. You'd be smarter to get a degree from WGU than to get it at a traditional brick and mortar school because not only will you not be in debt, you'll get done faster.

I'll let you in on something OP. WGU is revamping their software development degree and releasing a new degree program called software engineering in march. If you don't like math and want to accumulate more practical knowledge about programming and stuff, wait for march and enroll in the software engineering program; this is if your goal is to become a software engineer or codemonkey of course.

It's really no different than my community college experience as far as rigor goes. I've still learned a ton despite completing my courses faster than a traditional college attendee. They teach using textbooks (online) like any other college and depending on the course, you might be given a video course or lectures to study from. With any computer/tech field of study, you're still going to have to do work outside of class to get you prepared for the work force; ie building a portfolio to show to employers, learning desired tech stacks, etc. They do a great job at giving you a solid foundation to build upon.
>are they (WGU graduates) frowned upon by scientific publishers/academics in any way?
By pretentious snobs yes. However, with a degree from WGU, you can go on to graduate school at other universities if you really wanted to. >ow many course were you lift with after transferring credits?!
Like 23 or so. I was able to transfer in 33 credits from my associates degree which was able to cover the gen ed portion of the WGU degree. I've completed 84 credits thus far (equates to 51 credits and 14 credits this term which began in july and ends at the end of the month). Because of the new software engineering degree, I'm actually taking a two month break starting in january so I can migrate from the software development program into software engineering without having to wait until my next term which would've started in january and ended in june to be over. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27972585
Consooming is a form of "sacrifice." You take the productive social forces in society and have them end with your enjoyment. It makes YOU the end purpose of many other people's lives and efforts. When you do it with others it's a form of social bonding. When done for yourself it's just the nature of being a social elite. All societies in history operated this way. In our global age we have "democratized" the royal right of sacrifice to the majority of US citizens. Unfortunately, like Rome, this comes at the expense of those outside the Empire. You have three options in life, labor for someone else's sacrifice, sacrifice someone else's labor, or try to produce and sacrifice as little as humanely possible (transcending the production-consumption matrix). All options are difficult desu.

Basically just the minor ways to signal you're more composed then a 13 year old male
